Cut the Fat, Not the Flow

The development sector is drowning in intermediariesâ€”re-granting agencies, consultants, collectives, and collaboratives.....Too often, they justify their existence with buzzwords like â€œsystems change,â€ â€œcapacity building,â€ â€œecosystem,â€ and â€œplatforms,â€ while delivering little beyond roundtables with the same faces in new venues, glossy reports where fonts change more than the data, flashy websites, feel-good videos (about themselves), feel-sad videos (about communities), and databases no one trusts.

The problem isnâ€™t intermediationâ€”itâ€™s bad intermediation. When done well, intermediaries can aggregate demand, align incentives, allocate capital efficiently, and manage risk. But when they morph into self-reinforcing bureaucracies, they stall progress and drain resources, especially when led by people with no personal stake in the outcome. Low "skin in the game" means leaders enjoy asymmetric rewards without bearing consequences. They are insulated from failure, making them risk-averse and impact-light.

We need to rethink the chain. Funders must back proximate actors directly, invest in real capacity, and shift accountability from process to outcomes. The goal isnâ€™t fewer intermediariesâ€”itâ€™s better ones. The best ones are entrepreneurs. They put their credibility, sweat, and future on the line.
Communities donâ€™t need more gatekeepers. They need partners who deliver.

At Social Alpha, we work with bold innovators solving tough challengesâ€”from sustainable farming to equitable healthcare. As part of our Communications team, youâ€™ll get to turn their work into stories that matter.Â

As part of the #ProtoQuik Launchpad Cohort 1, we had the privilege of hosting Dr Amit Ray, a seasoned Naval Architect with the Indian Navy, for an insightful session on the future of marine robotics.

Bringing decades of domain expertise, Dr. Ray shed light on the real-world deployment of underwater systemsâ€”ranging from advanced firefighting technologies to the complexities of underwater navigation. He offered a deep dive into the operational trade-offs between AUVs and ROVs, while also unpacking challenges like energy constraints and communication blackouts in subsea environments.

His perspectives bridged defense and industry use casesâ€”offering our innovators a rare look into the nuanced demands of underwater robotics from someone who has navigated them firsthand.

Designing the Future: Smarter, Faster, Simulation-Driven

As part of the #ProtoQuik Launchpad Cohort 1, we hosted an in-depth session with experts from SOLIDWORKS and 3DEXPERIENCE Works, facilitated by Best Engineering Aids & Consultancies (BEACON India) â€” empowering Robotics innovators with a hands-on understanding of modern design and simulation workflows.

The session began with an introduction by Swapnil Barot, Regional Head â€“ Gujarat at BEACON India. This was followed by Ronak Kamani, who demonstrated how to build smarter and faster products using SOLIDWORKS.
The second half featured an advanced discussion on simulation-driven designâ€”including FEA, CFD, and EMAGâ€”led by Theophilus Dsouza and Venkatesh S S, helping participants explore how virtual testing and optimisation can significantly reduce development time and risk.

For the ProtoQuik Robotics cohort, it was a deep dive into building better, smarter, and more resilient systemsâ€”starting from the digital workspace.
